questions.text: Which of the following enzymes serves as a marker for the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is found in the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), specifically the smooth ER, where it plays a critical role in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose.
  • ER functions in gluconeogenesis, lipid synthesis, and protein folding.

questions.text: Which of the following membrane proteins do not require detergents for their solubilisation and release from the membrane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ankyrin is a peripheral membrane protein that is not embedded in the lipid bilayer and can be released by salt solutions-no detergents required.
  • Integral membrane proteins (e.g., ion channels, GPCRs, Glycophorin A) are embedded within the lipid bilayer and interact with the hydrophobic core of the membrane.
  • These require detergents to disrupt lipid-protein interactions and allow solubilization. (Options A, B and D ruled out)
  • Peripheral membrane proteins (e.g., Ankyrin, Spectrin) are bound to the polar head groups of lipids or to other integral membrane proteins.
  • These can be released by salt solutions of high ionic strength-no detergents needed.

questions.text: In which of the following membranes is the mass ratio of protein to lipid the highest?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The inner mitochondrial membrane has the highest protein-to-lipid ratio, owing to its dense packing of protein complexes involved in oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Membrane protein content is highly variable. The amount of proteins equals or exceeds the quantity of lipids in nearly all membranes. The outstanding exception is myelin, an electrical insulator found on many nerve fibres.

questions.text: Which of the following lipids is present in the highest amount by mass in the membranes of human cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The major lipids in mammalian membranes are phospholipids, glycosphingolipids & cholesterol.
  • Among these, phospholipids are the dominant lipid class, and within phospholipids, phosphatidylcholine (PC) is the most abundant phosphoglyceride by mass.

Explanation of other options:

Sphingomyelin (Option A): Important structural lipid, especially in neural tissue, but not the most abundant overall

Glycosphingolipid (Option B): Present in smaller amounts, mostly at the outer plasma membrane for signalling/recognition.

Cholesterol (Option D): Most abundant sterol, modulates membrane fluidity, but less by mass than phosphatidylcholine.

choices.text: Detergents are widely used to solubilise and purify membrane proteins
Membrane is permeable to most water-soluble molecules

questions.text: All of the following sentences are true regarding the plasma membrane, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The plasma membrane is composed primarily of a phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins and cholesterol. Its structure creates a hydrophobic core, making it a selective barrier.
  • Phospholipids are amphipathic, possessing both hydrophilic (polar) and hydrophobic (non-polar) regions. They spontaneously form bilayers in aqueous environments.
  • The hydrophobic interior of the membrane prevents free diffusion of most water-soluble (polar) substances such as ions, sugars, and amino acids. These substances require channel proteins or transporters to cross the membrane.

Explanation of other options:

Detergents are used for protein solubilization (Option A): Commonly used to extract and stabilise membrane proteins during biochemical analysis.

Membrane lipids form bilayers (Option B): Lipid bilayers are the foundational structure of biological membranes.

Membrane lipids are amphipathic (Option C): Amphipathic nature is crucial for bilayer formation and membrane dynamics.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules has the lowest permeability coefficient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sodium, being a charged ion, has the lowest permeability coefficient across lipid membranes due to the hydrophobic core acting as a strong barrier to polar and charged species.
  • The permeability coefficient is a measure of the ability of a molecule to diffuse across a permeability barrier.
  • Molecules that move rapidly through a given membrane are said to have a high permeability coefficient.

So Sodium has the lowest permeability coefficient than Glucose (Option B), Tryptophan (Option C) & Glycerol (Option D).

questions.text: Membranes are an asymmetric structure. Which of the following components is present in higher amounts in the inner leaflet of the membrane?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phospholipid asymmetry is a hallmark of biological membranes.

  • The inner (cytosolic) leaflet is enriched with: Phosphatidylethanolamine, also called cephalin, and
  • The outer leaflet contains: Phosphatidylcholine (lecithin)and (Options A and C ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Sugar (Option D) (glycoconjugates): Carbohydrates are usually attached to proteins/lipids on the outer surface of the plasma membrane

questions.text: The temperature at which the membrane structure undergoes the transition from ordered to disordered (melting) is called the transition temperature (Tm). The fluidity of membranes is dependent on the lipid composition of the membrane, especially fatty acids. Which of the following types of fatty acids will increase the Tm value?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Long-chain fatty acids increase the Tm because longer hydrocarbon chains result in stronger van der Waals interactions between fatty acid tails, making the membrane more rigid and requiring more heat (higher temperature) to disrupt.
  • The Tm (transition temperature) of membranes reflects how easily fatty acid chains within the bilayer shift from a rigid (gel-like) to a fluid It is affected by chain length and saturation:

Explanation of Other options:

Short chain fatty acids (Option A): Decrease Tm due to reduced chain interactions

Unsaturated fatty acids (Option C): Introduce kinks, disrupt alignment → lower Tm

Cis fatty acids (Option D): Increase membrane fluidity → lower ™

Key Takeaways:

  • Long saturated chains = high Tm (less fluid)
  • Short or unsaturated chains = low Tm (more fluid)
  • Membrane fluidity is essential for function and responsiveness

choices.text: It is an invagination in the plasma membrane.
A protein, caveolin, plays an important role in the formation of caveolae
Each caveolin monomer is anchored to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane
Caveolae may derive from lipid rafts.

questions.text: All of the following are features of caveola, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Caveolae are flask-shaped invaginations of the plasma membrane, enriched in cholesterol, sphingolipids, and the protein caveolin. (Option A)
  • They are considered specialised lipid raft (Option D) domains involved in:
    • Endocytosis
    • Signal transduction
    • Mechanical stress sensing
  • Caveolin, the structural protein essential for caveola formation, is anchored to the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane via palmitoyl anchors (fatty acyl modifications). (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the cross-membrane movement of large molecules?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cross-membrane movement of large molecules occurs by Endocytosis and Exocytosis
  • Exocytosis involves fusion of intracellular vesicles with the plasma membrane, allowing bulk release of substances like hormones and neurotransmitters.
  • Cross membrane movement of small molecules occurs by Passive or Simple diffusion (Option A), Facilitated diffusion (Option B) and Active transport (Option C).

questions.text: Which of the following filaments are termed microfilaments?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cytoskeleton is a dynamic network of filamentous proteins critical for cell shape, motility, division, and intracellular transport. It is composed of:
    • Microfilaments (Actin filaments)
    • Intermediate filaments (Option A ruled out)
    • Microtubules (Option C ruled out)
  • Actin filaments are the thinnest cytoskeletal fibres (diameter ~7 nm)
  • Composed of G-actin monomers that polymerise to form F-actin (filamentous)
  • Involved in:
  • Cell motility
  • Endocytosis and exocytosis
  • Cytokinesis
  • Membrane integrity

Found in stress fibres, microvilli, and cortical actin networks.

Explanation of other options:

Myosin filaments (Option D): Motor proteins, not structural filaments of the cytoskeleton.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male has a problem of infertility and chronic respiratory infection. He was probably diagnosed with Kartagener syndrome after many biochemical investigations. A mutation in the genes affecting the synthesis of which of the following proteins, which are involved in the movement of cilia and flagella, has been detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kartagener syndrome is a form of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).
  • It is caused by a genetic defect in dynein arms, leading to immotile cilia and flagella.
  • This results in:
    • Male infertility (due to immotile sperm)
    • Recurrent respiratory infections (due to impaired mucociliary clearance)
    • Situs inversus (in ~50% of cases)
  • Dynein, a microtubule-associated motor protein, provides ATP-powered movement along the minus end of microtubules. In axonemal cilia and flagella, dynein arms generate sliding forces required for motility.

Explanation of other options:

Kinesin (Option (A): Moves cargo toward the plus end of microtubules (anterograde axonal transport), not involved in cilia movement.

Dynamin (Option B): GTPase involved in endocytosis, not in ciliary or flagellar movement

Myosin (Option D): Motor protein for actin filaments, relevant to muscle contraction, not microtubule-based cilia

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male presents with gout and is prescribed a drug that targets microtubule polymerisation to alleviate symptoms by inhibiting leukocyte chemotaxis. While reviewing his medication history, you note he is also receiving antifungal therapy and has previously undergone chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma.
Which of the following medications in his list does not act by binding to microtubules?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ciprofloxacin does not affect microtubules but inhibits bacterial DNA topoisomerase and gyrase.
  • Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that functions by inhibiting DNA replication in bacteria.
  • It targets bacterial DNA topoisomerase II (gyrase) and topoisomerase IV, thus preventing DNA unwinding during replication. It does not interfere with microtubule function and is unrelated to the cytoskeletal system.

Explanation of other options:

Colchicine (Option B): Binds to tubulin and prevents microtubule polymerisation, used in the treatment of acute gout to block leukocyte chemotaxis.

Vinblastine (Option C): A vinca alkaloid that binds to tubulin and inhibits mitotic spindle formation, commonly used in chemotherapy.

Griseofulvin (Option D: An antifungal agent that binds to fungal microtubules and disrupts mitosis by interfering with the mitotic spindle.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male presents with signs of premature ageing, including alopecia, wrinkled skin, and skeletal abnormalities. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the LMNA gene, which encodes lamin A, a nuclear structural protein. Lamins belong to which of the following classes of cytoskeletal filaments?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lamins are a subtype of intermediate filaments, specifically located in the nuclear lamina.
  • They provide mechanical support to the nuclear envelope and are crucial for nuclear shape, integrity, and chromatin organisation.
  • Lamin A mutations cause Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome (HGPS), a rare disorder marked by accelerated ageing due to defective nuclear scaffolding.

Explanation of other options:

Microfilaments (Option B): Composed of actin; involved in motility and shape, not nuclear structure.

Microtubules (Option C): Composed of tubulin; function in transport, mitotic spindle, and organelle positioning.

Muscle filaments (Option D): Composed of actin and myosin in muscle tissue; not related to lamins.

choices.text: Occurs due to a defect in the carbonic anhydrase II enzyme
Characterised by inability of resorb bone

questions.text: All of the following are true about Osteopetrosis, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Osteopetrosis (also known as marble bone disease) is a rare genetic disorder characterised by abnormally increased bone density due to defective bone resorption by osteoclasts.
  • Osteopetrosis occurs due to mutations in the gene (located on chromosome 8q22) encoding carbonic anhydrase II (CA II), one of four isozymes of carbonic anhydrase present in human tissues. (Option A)
  • Deficiency of CA II in osteoclasts prevents normal bone resorption, and osteopetrosis results (Option C).
  • One form osteopetrosis is associated with renal tubular acidosis and cerebral calcification. (Option D)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was observed to have many skeletal abnormalities and short-limbed dwarfism. It is an inherited disorder leading to chondrodysplasia and mainly affecting cartilage. Which type of collagen will be abnormal in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chondrodysplasias are a mixed group of hereditary disorders affecting cartilage. They are manifested by short-limbed dwarfism and numerous skeletal deformities.
  • A few are due to a variety of mutations in the COL2A1 gene, leading to abnormal forms of type II collagen.
  • Chondrodysplasias are caused by mutations in genes encoding type II collagen & fibroblast growth factor receptors.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: All of the following extracellular matrix (ECM) components are present in the glomerular membrane, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fibronectin, though abundant in the interstitial ECM, is not a major component of the glomerular basement membrane. It is primarily involved in wound healing, cell adhesion, and migration in the interstitial matrix, not the basal lamina.

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is a specialized ECM structure forming part of the renal filtration barrier. It consists primarily of:

  • Laminin: a large, cross-shaped glycoprotein that interacts with integrins and dystroglycans on epithelial cells. (Option A)
  • Type IV collagen: provides structural integrity to the basement membrane. (Option C)
  • Entactin (Nidogen): a sulfated glycoprotein that serves as a cross-linker between laminin and collagen IV. (Option B)
  • Perlecan: a heparan sulfate proteoglycan that contributes to charge-selective

questions.text: All of the following attachment proteins indirectly interact with fibronectin receptor with actin microfilaments, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Elastin is a structural protein of the ECM responsible for tissue elasticity (e.g., skin, lungs, arteries). It plays no role in linking integrins to the actin cytoskeleton.
  • Fibronectin is a high-molecular-weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix (ECM) that binds to membrane-spanning integrins (fibronectin receptors) and links the ECM to the actin cytoskeleton via a complex of adaptor proteins.
  • The intracellular linkage is mediated by several actin-binding proteins, including:
  • Talin binds directly to the β-subunit of integrins and connects to actin. (Option A)
  • Vinculin reinforces talin-actin linkage and stabilises focal adhesions. (Option B)
  • Paxillin functions as a scaffold protein that integrates signals from integrins and growth factor receptors. (Option C)
  • Alpha-actinin crosslinks actin filaments and anchors them to integrin complexes.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old tall boy presents with long fingers (arachnodactyly), hyperextensible joints, and a history of frequent dislocations. On ophthalmologic examination, he is found to have ectopia lentis. Echocardiography shows dilatation of the ascending aorta.
Which of the following proteins is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of tall stature, arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis, and aortic root dilatation strongly suggests Marfan syndrome due to a Fibrillin-1 defect.
  • Marfan syndrome is a relatively prevalent inherited disease affecting connective tissue; it is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
  • It affects the eyes (eg, causing dislocation of the lens, known as ectopia lentis), the skeletal system (most patients are tall and exhibit long digits [arachnodactyly] and hyperextensibility of the joints), and the cardiovascular system (eg, causing weakness of the aortic media, leading to dilation of the ascending aorta).
  • Most cases are caused by mutations in the gene (on chromosome 15) for fibrillin-1.
  • This results in abnormal fibrillin and/or lower amounts being deposited in the ECM.
  • Since the cytokine transforming growth factor β (TGF-β) normally binds to fibrillin-1, decreased binding in Marfan syndrome causes disturbances in TGF-β signalling.

Explanation of other options:

Collagen Type II (Option A): Major component of cartilage, not implicated in Marfan syndrome.

Elastin (Option B): Functionally affected in Marfan syndrome, but the primary defect is not in the elastin gene.

Collagen Type IV (Option D): Component of basement membranes; associated with Alport syndrome, not Marfan.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules is least likely to be a component of the ECM involved in providing structural or adhesive support?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cadherins are calcium-dependent adhesion molecules that mediate cell-to-cell interactions, not cell-to-matrix interactions. Therefore, they are not part of the ECM, which provides structural integrity and anchorage for cells via interactions between ECM components and integrins.
  • Most mammalian cells are located in tissues where they are surrounded by a complex extracellular matrix (ECM), often referred to as connective tissue, which protects the organs and also provides elasticity where required (eg, in blood vessels, lungs, and skin).
  • The ECM contains three major classes of biomolecules:
    • Structural proteins, for example, collagen, elastin, and fibrillin; (Option C)
    • Specialised proteins such as fibronectin and laminin (Option D)
    • Proteoglycans (Option A)

choices.text: Alpha chain winds around in a left-handed helix
Proline and hydroxyproline confer flexibility to collagen molecules
A glycosylation site in collagen contain O - glycosidic linkage

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structure of collagen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hydroxylysine residues in collagen can be post-translationally modified by the addition of galactose or galactosyl-glucose through O-glycosidic These O-glycosylation sites are important for proper fibril formation and intermolecular interactions.
  • Collagen is a structural protein that forms a triple helical superstructure, not a double helix (Option A ruled out).
  • Each α-chain forms a left-handed helix, and three such α-chains wind together to form a right-handed triple helix (Option B ruled out)
  • Proline and hydroxyproline play a vital role in stabilising the triple helix by causing kinks and limiting flexibility - they confer rigidity, not flexibility (Option C ruled out).

questions.text: Which among the following diseases is not related to collagen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Wilson's disease is unrelated to collagen. It is a disorder of copper metabolism, due to an ATP7B gene mutation, leading to hepatic and neurological manifestations.

Explanation of other options:

Menkes disease (Option A) is linked to collagen defects. It arises due to a copper deficiency resulting in defective cross-linking of collagen and elastin, caused by reduced activity of lysyl oxidase, a copper-dependent enzyme.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option B) is a group of connective tissue disorders involving defects in collagen synthesis, typically affecting types I, III, and V.

Alport syndrome (Option C) is associated with mutations affecting Type IV collagen, a major component of basement membranes, particularly in the glomerulus, cochlea, and eyes.

choices.text: Elastin is encoded by multiple genetic variants
Intramolecular desmosine cross-links are characteristic of elastin
Glycosylation is a unique post-translational feature of elastin

questions.text: Which one of the following sentences is true about Elastin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Elastin contains unique intramolecular desmosine cross-links, which provide elasticity and recoil. These cross-links are formed between lysine residues and are specific to elastin. Collagen contains intramolecular aldol cross-links.
  • Elastin is encoded by a single gene, unlike collagen, which has multiple genetic types (e.g., Type I, II, III, IV, etc.) (Option A ruled out)
  • Elastin does not contain hydroxylysine, a residue typically found in collagen where it plays a role in cross-linking and (Option C)
  • Glycosylation is not a feature of elastin. This post-translational modification is more characteristic of collagen. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory measurements is most appropriate for estimating total body radical burden?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The total body radical burden is most accurately estimated by assessing the products of lipid peroxidation. These include lipid peroxides and dialdehydes, which are by-products of oxidative stress on membrane lipids.
  • Lipid peroxides are commonly quantified using the ferrous oxidation in xylenol orange (FOX) assay.
  • Under acidic conditions, Fe²+ is oxidised to Fe³+, forming a chromophore with xylenol orange, allowing quantification.
  • Dialdehydes, such as malondialdehyde (MDA), are detected using the thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) assay, which yields a red fluorescent product.

Explanation of other options:

Products of lipid reduction (Option B): These are not associated with oxidative stress; reduction implies removal of radicals, not their burden.

Product of protein breakdown (Option C): Indicates proteolysis, which is not specific to oxidative radical damage.

Product of protein reduction (Option D): Refers to non-radical-related processes and is not indicative of oxidative injury.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lipid peroxidation products, such as MDA and lipid hydroperoxides, serve as reliable biomarkers for assessing the body's oxidative stress level.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a negative acute-phase protein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transthyretin, also known as prealbumin, whose level is decreased during inflammation, so termed a negative acute phase protein.
  • Acute Phase Proteins
  • Those plasma proteins whose levels are changed in plasma (> 25%) during inflammations(as a result of any infection, injury, malignancy, surgery, etc) are known as Acute Phase Proteins or Acute Phase Reactants.
  • Such an acute-phase response is a nonspecific response and is associated with a characteristic pattern of changes in such proteins.
  • Some mediators like cytokines (IL-1, IL-6), tumour necrosis factors α and β, Interferons, platelet activating factor, etc, cause changes in such protein levels.

C-reactive protein (CRP)

  • Major acute-phase proteins
  • Beta globulin
  • It involves in promotion of the immune system through the activation of the complement cascade.
  • Produced in the liver and is present in circulation in minute concentration (<1 mg/dl)
  • Estimation of CRP in serum is important for the evaluation of the acute phase response during inflammation. It increases when inflammation is aggressive & decreases when inflammation subsides.
  • Preferred over ESR as changes are reflected earlier.
  • High sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) level in blood has a positive correlation with predicting the risk of coronary artery diseases.
